skill.name: using-superpowers
skill.description: Meta-skill enforcing skill discovery and invocation discipline through mandatory workflows. Use when starting any conversation to check for relevant skills before any response, ensuring skill-first workflow before proceeding.
skill.summary: Meta-skill enforcing skill discovery and invocation discipline through mandatory workflows. Use when...
skill.author: CodingCossack

security_audit.summary: This is a documentation-only meta-skill containing no executable code. All 15 static findings are false positives caused by the scanner misinterpreting markdown documentation and JSON metadata as security-sensitive patterns. The skill provides workflow guidelines only.

content.value_statement: Stop wasting time on undisciplined approaches. This meta-skill forces you to check for relevant skills before every response, ensuring you follow proven workflows instead of improvising.
actual_capabilities: Forces skill check before any response
Creates todo items from skill checklists
Distinguishes rigid vs flexible skill types
limitations: Cannot force skill usage, only guide

use_cases.title: Maintain Workflow Discipline
use_cases.description: Stop yourself from skipping important workflows by always checking for relevant skills first.

use_cases.title: Standardize AI Interactions
use_cases.description: Ensure team members follow consistent, skill-based approaches to problem-solving.

use_cases.title: Promote Skill Adoption
use_cases.description: Help users discover and properly utilize the skills available in your library.

prompt_templates.title: Basic Skill Check
prompt_templates.prompt: Before responding, check if any skills apply to this request. Even a 1% chance means you must use the Skill tool first.

prompt_templates.title: Multiple Skills
prompt_templates.prompt: Check for process skills first (brainstorming, debugging), then implementation skills. Create todos for each checklist item.

prompt_templates.title: Resist Rationalization
prompt_templates.scenario: When you think this is simple
prompt_templates.prompt: This thought is a red flag. Check for skills before proceeding. Simple tasks become complex without discipline.

prompt_templates.title: Skill Evolution
prompt_templates.prompt: Skills evolve. Always read the current version instead of relying on memory.

output_examples.input: Help me build a web scraper
output: Using brainstorming skill to identify the best approach
Creating todo items from the skill checklist
Following the skill workflow for implementation

output_examples.input: Fix the authentication bug in my app
output: Using debugging skill to diagnose the issue

best_practices: Always announce which skill you are using and why
Create todos for every checklist item in skills
anti_patterns: Thinking this is just a simple question
Believing you need context before checking skills
Assuming you remember what a skill does

faq.question: Why must I check skills before clarifying questions?
faq.answer: Skills often contain the clarification process. Checking first ensures you follow the right approach.

faq.question: What if no skills apply to my task?
faq.answer: Only proceed without skills if you are certain none apply. When in doubt, check first.

faq.question: How do I handle multiple applicable skills?
faq.answer: Use process skills first, then implementation skills. The skill itself will guide priority.

faq.question: Can I adapt rigid skills to my situation?
faq.answer: No. Rigid skills like TDD and debugging must be followed exactly to maintain discipline.

faq.question: What if the user gives specific instructions?
faq.answer: Instructions describe what to accomplish, not how. Still use skills for the process.

faq.question: How often should I re-read skills?
faq.answer: Every time. Skills evolve and your memory may be outdated. Always read the current version.
